txt.en: 'We were trying to bring peace and prosperity to Umbar.'
'Nakási lost sight of that when she abducted the child Thorongil.'
Talk to Belondor at the Hungry Deep Tavern
'She will still pay for that crime. I have not forgotten.'
Stand by Sirgon while he meets with Belondor
Talk to Mêshka at the Hungry Deep Tavern
Stand by Sirgon while he meets with Belondor
Talk to Sirgon at the Hungry Deep Tavern
Remain alert to see what Rothog will do
Talk to Belondor at the Hungry Deep Tavern
'They are the crew of the Wave-hunter, captained by [placeholder].'
'I value their friendship most highly, and yet...'
Talk to Rothog at the Hungry Deep Tavern
Belondor has suggested that Sirgon meet with him at the Hungry Deep Tavern, but it will be best if you and your crew attend the meeting as well... for the safety of all involved.
'What use is my friendship, when those I hold most dear come to the greatest harm?'
'Aye.'
'So it was with the Steward Denethor.'
'He changed. I know not the cause, but his mind became clouded and his heart was hardened.'
'Gwallang!'
'Gwallang, it is all right.'
'We are not in danger.'
'What am I hearing, Belondor?'
'Does this man turn you against the Kindred?'
'Bird?'
'I like that bird. He is afraid of nothing!'
Talk to Sirgon below the Hungry Deep Tavern
Climb up to the Hungry Deep Tavern with Sirgon
'So! You have come back!'
Stand by Sirgon while he meets with Belondor
'I have heard his honest words.'
'They do not excuse the hurts he and his master inflicted upon us.'
'I appreciate you and the crew of the Wave-hunter agreeing to accompany me to this meeting with Belondor, [placeholder].\n\n'The Hungry Deep, and my fate, awaits me atop these steps.'

'Beneath the Mâkhda Khorbo he worked cruel magic, tearing the life from dear members of my crew, friends I have known for years. They died trusting me, Sirgon. They trusted I would bring them to safety, and trusted that their families would know they did not die for nothing.\n\n'But Azagath spent their lives for no purpose! Their deaths were needless, and provided only the smallest of delays so the Sea-shadow could make his escape! He did not know those men, and he discarded them without thought... only I am left to suffer the grief of their loss.'

'I warned your friend Sirgon not to return to the Upper Ward! Does he think he remains out of reach and free from justice?\n\n'Rothog has slain many such men who believed themselves to be untouchable, and for less reason that this. Belondor has not forgotten how easily Sirgon cast aside his long friendship and was rewarded for it! He followed the Steward Denethor's commands, and questioned them not!'

'I know my words are just words, Belondor, and I have given you little reason to believe them. But I speak this from my heart: King Elessar is a good man, and he desires only what is best for his people and for yours. He wants peace between Gondor and Umbar, and prosperity for both.\n\n'I know this is so. He is not the same as the Steward Denethor. Can the Kindred of the Coins come to see this, if Azagath no longer controls them? Can you, and they, work alongside the kingdom of Gondor, and not against it? Can you join hands with King Elessar, if it means setting aside war and conflict?'
Rothog the Storm has questions for Belondor.
Belondor wishes to speak with you at the Hungry Deep Tavern.

'I hope we have repaired something of the friendship we once possessed, Sirgon, but I am not ready to say the same of that between Gondor and Umbar. Your King has much to prove to us, for we have heard sweet words before, and were deceived. It will not happen again.\n\n'The Kindred of the Coins will survive without Azagath and Nakási. It was larger than both of them. It is larger than all of us, for it is Umbar. Your King will need to realize that if he believes there can be peace between our lands.'
Rothog the Storm has something to say to you.

'What kind of bird was that?'

You tell Rothog that the bird's name is Gwallang, and he is a Limlinn from across the Bay of Belfalas.

'Gwallang. Limlinn. I have not heard these names before. He is brave for one so small.

'But I came here for two purposes: to fight, and to fetch. I am disappointed there was no fight, but now you will come with me.

'Hármelak wants to see you again.'

'Gondorians and Umbari are both alike in this: each of them uses too many words.

'I came here for two purposes: to fight, and to fetch. I am disappointed there was no fight, but now you will come with me.

'Hármelak wants to see you again.'
Sirgon waits below the stairs that climb to the Hungry Deep Tavern.
'What am I hearing, Belondor?'
'Does this man turn you against the Kindred?'
'And Azagath!'
'The man I knew would not have slain the child, not for any reason.'
'What changed in him to consider such reckless slaughter?'
'So it is true. You really have come to Umbar.'
'I served Umbar, and you Gondor.'
With an angry chirp, Gwallang flies down and settles onto Rothog's curved blade
'I did not think it could be so.'
'When did each of them cease serving us?'
With one last aggressive trill, Gwallang flies back to a safer perch
'And yet I see many strange patrons here at the Hungry Deep.'
'They must be friends of yours, if friendship with Sirgon can yet exist.'
You have agreed to stand by Sirgon with much of your crew while he meets with Belondor.
'You would die for them, and they for you?'
You have agreed to stand by Sirgon with much of your crew while he meets with Belondor.
'My own crew was the same.'
Belondor wants to speak with you about the events that transpired beneath the Mâkhda Khorbo.
'Though all the forces of Gondor be arrayed against us, they would stand with me against them.'
'But Azagath spent their lives with nary a thought.'
You have agreed to stand by Sirgon with much of your crew while he meets with Belondor.
'I am just so tired, Sirgon.'
Belondor's wife Mêshka has arrived at the Hungry Deep Tavern, and she is not pleased to see that Sirgon has violated her ban upon returning to the Upper Ward.
You have agreed to stand by Sirgon with much of your crew while he meets with Belondor.
Sirgon is compelled to speak on behalf of King Elessar.
'For so long my hatred consumed me.'
'Hatred of you, hatred of Denethor your master, hatred of Gondor.'
'It wears out a man, such hatred as that.'
'The Steward Denethor is dead, Mêshka.'
'Sirgon came here to speak honest words with me.'
Instance: Gondor and Umbar
'No.'
'But I have come to understand the snare in which he was caught.'
'The Kindred of the Coins was supposed to be different!'
